summary: This document is a chain of email correspondence from May 2020 between individuals, likely prosecutors and law enforcement agents, regarding the tracking down of FBI 302 interview reports and underlying handwritten notes for a large number of interviews (over 120) in the Epstein case. The emails discuss specific missing documents, date discrepancies, and interview details.

events.title: Interview with [Redacted]
events.description: Mention of a meeting/interview with an individual in October 2019, for which there are both a 302 and notes.

events.title: Prior FBI interviews
events.description: Reference to prior FBI interviews with an individual conducted in 2006.

events.title: Prior FBI interviews
events.description: Reference to prior FBI interviews with an individual conducted in 2007.

events.title: Puzzling 302 Report Date
events.description: A 302 report with a system-generated date of 12/04/18 is discussed; the sender does not recall an interview in 2018, suggesting a possible glitch or misdated document.

events.title: Interview with [Redacted]
events.description: A very short 302 from an interview on this date is referenced; it is questioned whether any handwritten notes exist.

keyFacts: The correspondence reveals an extensive investigation with 'more than 120 interviews' conducted in the case.
There is active effort and confusion among officials in May 2020 to locate and reconcile all FBI 302 reports and their underlying handwritten interview notes.
A specific 302 report dated 12/04/18 is flagged as puzzling because the sender does not recall an interview in 2018, and the date may be a system glitch.
The emails reference interviews from as early as 2006 and 2007, indicating a long investigative timeline.
Many names of interviewees and agents are redacted in the released text, indicating the sensitivity of the identities involved.
